children.value: This is one in a series of python jupyter notebooks on Trade models by Jonathan Conning

the plots and simulations below are written in python. This notebook can be run interactively on a jupyter server, on your own machine or on a cloud serve such as Googles Colab.  However, much of the code is in a separate
module. You can also view this notebook in slideshow mode (Alt-R) if the proper extension is installed.

import sys
from ipywidgets import interact, interact_manual, fixed
Warm up:  Budget lines and Indifference curves

Move the sliders to change prices and income values.

children.value: The negative slope shows that there is a tradeoff:

children.value: workers to produce one more unit of good X.
With full employment we can only get this labor by pulling them out of Y production.
Each worker there would have produced

children.html: MPLY=1MPL_Y=1MPLY=1
1MPLX\frac{1}{MPL_X}MPLX1

children.value: workers will reduce Y output by

children.html: MPLYMPLX=21(unitsofYunitsofX)\frac{MPL_Y}{MPL_X} = \frac{2}{1} \left ( \frac{\text{units of Y}}{\text{units of X}} \right )MPLXMPLY=12(unitsofXunitsofY)

children.value: Hence (negative of) the slope tells us the opportunity cost of an extra unit of good X, measured in terms of units of good Y which must be given up.

Firms will earn profit and want to hire more workers so long as the marginal value product of labor exceeds the market wage. Competition between firms and workers moving across firms and sectors in search of the highest wage will drive profits to zero at which the following market equilibrium conditions must hold:

children.html: PXMPLX=w=PYMPLYP_X \cdot MPL_X = w = P_Y \cdot MPL_YPXMPLX=w=PYMPLY

children.value: All workers are paid the same wage which will be equal to their marginal value product, which is equalized across firms and sectors.

children.html: www

children.value: is measured in dollars. From the zero profit condition we can determine real wages:
\frac{w}{P_X} = MPL_X = 2 \, \,\,\, \text{(units of good X per unit of labor)}

of this nominal wage in terms of good

children.value: In this competitive economy workers are paid a real wage equal to their marginal product (which in the Ricardian model is also equal to their average product).  Workers are the only factor of production and firm profits are driven to zero so workers get all of the output in the economy.

children.html: wPX\frac{w}{P_X}PXw
wPY\frac{w}{P_Y}PYw

children.value: different wages for workers in each sector. They are just two different ways to measure the real purchasing power of a workers wage

children.html: www

children.value: There is only one wage in the economy
and all workers earn the same wage no matter what sector or firm they work in!
Its easy to determine real wages from just eyeballing the PPF graph, if you know the size of the labor force.  In the plot real GDP
measured in terms of good X
is 400 units and since there are 100 workers each worker gets paid a real wage of 4 units of X.  If
real GDP is measured instead in terms of good Y
real GDP is 200 units of Y and since there are 100 workers each worker gets paid a real wage of 2 units of Y.
We could also define a real wage in terms of any arbitrary basket of goods. For example, let

children.value: domestic (or closed economy) relative price of

YYY
PXPY=MPLYMPLX\frac{P_X}{P_Y} = \frac{MPL_Y}{MPL_X}PYPX=MPLXMPLY

children.value: which is equal to the slope of the PPF.  Relative prices reflect opportunity costs.

Note that in this Ricardian model with linear production technologies we have determined equilibrium relative prices without having to specify consumer preferences or demand!  This will not be the case in more general models.
Visible/interactive if running a jupyter server.
Home opens to Trade  --  Gains to Trade

children.label: Home opens to Trade  --  Gains to Trade

children.value: Suppose Home has these technologies and resources:

children.html: MPLX=1unitsofX/workerMPLY=2unitsofX/workerL=100workersMPL_X^* = 1 \text{ units of X/worker} \\ MPL_Y^* = 2 \text{ units of X/worker} \\ \bar L^* = 100 \text{ workers}MPLX=1unitsofX/workerMPLY=2unitsofX/workerL=100workers

children.value: opportunity cost of producing one unit of good X
measured in terms of good Y at Home is:

children.html: PXPY=MPLYMPLX=12\frac{P_X}{P_Y}=\frac{MPL_Y}{MPL_X}= \frac{1}{2}PYPX=MPLXMPLY=21

children.value: Homes autarky relative price of producing good X
If the world relative price of good X is

children.html: pxwpyw=1\frac{p_x^w}{p_y^w} = 1pywpxw=1

children.value: units of Y then Home is a relatively low cost producer of good X (since 1/2 units of Y per X < 1 units of Y per X). Given Homes technologies and these world prices Home has a
comparative advantage in the production of good X

If it opens up to trade producers will find it profitable to continue to expand X production (at the expense of Y production) until the country becomes specialied in the production of X.    At that point the countrys GDP will be

children.html: MPLXLMPL_X \cdot \bar LMPLXL

children.value: units of good X which it can trade to the world at the world price of 1 unit of good Y per X.  Hence the citizens of the Home country can consume along the
given by the world price line running through the specialization point

children.html: (qx=MPLxLandqy=0)(q_x=MPL_x\cdot \bar L and q_y = 0)(qx=MPLxLandqy=0)

children.value: The specialized economy is depicted below.
Technologies and hence domestic relative prices are different in two countries.

children.html: MPLX=2MPLY=1MPL_X = 2 \\ MPL_Y = 1MPLX=2MPLY=1
MPLX=1MPLY=2MPL_X^* = 1 \\ MPL_Y^* = 2MPLX=1MPLY=2

children.value: The autarky relative price of X is

children.html: MPLYMPLX=12\frac{MPL_Y}{MPL_X} = \frac{1}{2}MPLXMPLY=21

children.value: units of good Y per X

children.html: MPLYMPLX=21\frac{MPL_Y^*}{MPL_X^*} = \frac{2}{1}MPLXMPLY=12

children.value: units of good Y per X
Home has a comparative advantage at producing X as it is the lower cost producer.

children.html: pxpy=34\frac{p_x^*}{p_y^*}=\frac{3}{4}pypx=43

children.value: units of good Y per X, Home will specialize at X production and Foreign at Y production, but trade will not balance.

qx, qy, cx, cy = openeq(mplx=2, mply=1, lbar=100, pw=3/4)
print(f'qx = {qx}, qy = {qy}, cx = {cx}, cy = {cy}')
print(f'Home exports {qx-cx} units of good X and imports {cy-qy} units of good Y')

jupyter_data.text:
qx = 200, qy = 0, cx = 100.0, cy = 75.0
Home exports 100.0 units of good X and imports 75.0 units of good Y

children.value: rtwopane(mplx=2, mply=1, lbar=100, mplfx=1, mplfy=2, lbarf=100, p=1)

Broadly speaking, the world equilibrium price will be that price at which one countrys exports equal the other countrys imports. It should be pretty clear that it will lie somewhere between the closed-economy relative prices of each country. In the example above Home autarky relative price of good X was

children.html: PxPy=12\frac{P_x}{P_y}=\frac{1}{2}PyPx=21

children.value: , the foreign autarky relative price was

children.html: PxPy=2\frac{P_x}{P_y}=2PyPx=2

children.value: and the world equilibrium price that balances trade is

children.html: PxePye=1\frac{P_x^e}{P_y^e}=1PyePxe=1

children.value: Since we can determine the quantity of exports and imports in each country at any world price, we could try to find the equilibrium price by trial and error -- by increasing or decreasing the world relative price until trade balances. Lets start with that idea:

interact(rtwopane, mplx=fixed(2), mply=fixed(1), lbar=fixed(100),  mplfx=(0.5,2,0.1), mplfy=(0.5,2,0.1), 
         lbarf=(50, 200, 10),p=(0.2,3,0.1));
To find a world equilibrium price consistent with balanced trade we only need to find where the market for one good clears.  The
function finds this relative price numerically as the price at which world excess demand for good X is to zero.
rworldprice(mplx=2, mply=1, lbar=100, mplfx=1, mplfy=2, lbarf=100)

qxf, qyf, cxf, cyf  = openeq2(mplx=2, mply=0.5, lbar=90, pw=pp)
qx, qy, cx, cy  = openeq2(mplx=1, mply=2, lbar=100, pw=pp)
